title: 110_hr3059
content: Increased average fuel economy standards. Increased average fuel economy standards for non-passenger automobiles to a minimum of 27.5 miles per gallon for model year 2022 and subsequent years. Regulations for passenger automobiles' fuel economy standards to be set 18 months before each model year. The Secretary shall prescribe average fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles manufactured by a manufacturer for model year 2022 and subsequent years, with a minimum standard of 35 miles per gallon. The alternative minimum standard for passenger automobiles manufactured domestically shall be the greater of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in a model year. The alternative minimum standard for domestically manufactured passenger automobiles is determined by the greater of 27.5 miles per gallon or 92 percent of the average fuel economy projected by the Secretary for all manufacturers in a model year. This standard applies if the manufacturer's average fuel economy standard for passenger automobiles would allow compliance with a less stringent standard. If standards are prescribed based on vehicle attributes, a transition period is provided during the first 3 model years. The Secretary prescribes standards for passenger automobiles based on vehicle attributes, allowing a transition period for manufacturers to comply with either the attribute-based standard or the single corporate average fuel economy level. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with existing standards for passenger automobiles remaining in effect until a new standard is established. The Act allows for a transition period for passenger automobiles to comply with new standards. Technical and conforming amendments are made to Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code. The Act includes amendments to Chapter 329 of title 49, United States Code, regarding compliance standards for passenger automobiles. Amendments include changes to subsections (g), (h), and (j) of section 32902, as well as adjustments to section 32903. In section 32903, amendments involve changing references to subsections and clarifying terminology. Additionally, section 32909(b) is modified by removing certain language related to petition review. SEC. 2. CREDIT TRANSFERRING WITHIN A MANUFACTURER'S FLEET. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a credit transferring program for manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet. Credits can be applied to compliance categories that do not meet standards, with a maximum increase of 1.0 mile per gallon in a single model year. Transfers to certain categories are limited based on the manufacturer's fleet fuel economy level. The credit transferring program allows manufacturers to transfer fuel economy credits within their fleet, with a maximum increase of 1.0 mile per gallon in a single model year. Transfers are limited for certain categories based on the manufacturer's fleet fuel economy level, excluding transfers from other categories. Credits can only be transferred if earned in model year 2010 or later. The term 'compliance category of automobiles' refers to the 3 categories for which compliance is separately calculated under this chapter: passenger automobiles manufactured domestically, passenger automobiles not manufactured domestically, and non-passenger automobiles. The Secretary of Transportation will partner with industry groups to create a public education campaign on fuel conservation for drivers. The campaign will use various methods to reach a wide audience and the Secretary will provide up to 50% of the campaign's cost, with the option to accept private funds. Funding will be authorized as needed for this program.
